description: Expresses the purpose of coming to a place; 'come to (do something)'
formation: Verb (ます-stem) + に + 来ます
explanation:
### Name
- Vます形＋に来ます（目的）

### Meaning and function
- Expresses coming to a place for the purpose of doing something (“come to do X”). Focuses on intended purpose of the movement toward the speaker’s location or a contextually “here” place.

### Form and templates
- Core
  - N(Place) に／へ + V(ます-stem) に + 来る／来ます
  - V(ます-stem) に + 来る／来ます（when the place is understood or already given）
- With する-verbs
  - N(サ変) しに + 来る／来ます
  - N(サ変) に + 来る／来ます（many activity nouns allow this; しに is often clearer）
- With an object of the purpose verb
  - N(object) を + V(ます-stem) に + 来る／来ます
- Particle requirements and ordering
  - Destination: に or へ（に is more common; へ is directional/softer）
  - Purpose: に only（へ cannot replace the purpose に）
  - Typical order: [Time] に + [Place] に／へ + [Object] を + [V(ます-stem)] に + 来る／来ます
  - Multiple に in one clause (time, place, purpose) is normal.
- Conjugation notes (来る is irregular)
  - Polite: 来ます／来ました／来ません／来ませんでした
  - Plain: 来る／来た／来ない／来なかった
  - て-form: 来て
  - Readings: 来る(くる), 来ます(きます), 来ない(こない), 来て(きて)

### Usage notes and constraints
- Register and frequency
  - Very common and neutral; use 来ます in polite speech and 来る in plain. In formal business or visiting superiors, the humble alternatives 参ります／伺います are used with the same purpose に.
- Direction/perspective
  - 来る is used when the movement is toward where the speaker is (or a place treated as “here” in the discourse). Use 行く when the movement is away from “here.”
- Semantics
  - Marks intended purpose of the movement; it does not itself assert that the action was (or will be) completed.
- Noun constraints
  - The purpose に must attach to a verb stem or an action noun (サ変名詞). Non-action nouns generally cannot directly express purpose with に; use a verb or a suitable action noun instead.
- Orthography
  - 来 is usually written in kanji (来る／来ます). Kana (くる／きます) also appears in beginners’ materials or casual text.

### Common mistakes (optional, only if relevant)
- Using V(辞書形)＋に来る instead of V(ます-stem)＋に来る.
- Replacing the purpose に with へ after the verb stem (Vます-stem＋へ is ungrammatical for purpose).
- Choosing 来る when the movement is actually away from “here” (should be 行く), or vice versa.
- Avoiding “double に” (destination に and purpose に); this is acceptable and common.
- Using non-action nouns after に to state purpose; use a verb stem or a サ変名詞 (often with しに).

### Related grammar (optional, only if relevant)
- V(ます-stem)＋に行く: “go to do”; same formation but movement is away from “here.”
- V(ます-stem)＋に帰る: “return (home/back) to do”; purpose with the movement verb 帰る.
- V(辞書形)ために＋来る／Nのために＋来る: “come in order to/for the sake of”; more explicit/formal purpose; not limited to movement verbs in other uses.
- Vて来る: “do and then come (here)” or “a change comes about toward the speaker”; expresses sequence/result, not purpose.

examples.jp: 今日は駅に友だちを迎えに来ます。
examples.en: I’ll come to the station today to pick up a friend.

examples.jp: 明日の朝九時に会社に書類を提出しに来てください。
examples.en: Please come to the office at 9 tomorrow morning to submit the documents.

examples.jp: 子どもたちは図書館へ本を借りに来た。
examples.en: The kids came to the library to borrow books.

examples.jp: 部長はさっき、状況を説明しに来ました。
examples.en: The manager came just now to explain the situation.

examples.jp: すみません、今日は練習しに来ません。
examples.en: Sorry, I’m not coming to practice today.

examples.jp: さっきは何をしに来たの？
examples.en: What did you come to do earlier?

examples.jp: お昼にこちらへ支払いに来ますか。
examples.en: Will you come here at lunchtime to make the payment?

examples.jp: 友だちが手伝いに来てくれて、本当に助かった。
examples.en: A friend came to help, and it really saved me.

examples.jp: 誰も相談にこないので、今日は静かだ。
examples.en: Since no one is coming to consult, it’s quiet today.

examples.jp: 来週の金曜日に市役所に申請しに来ますか。
examples.en: Will you come to city hall next Friday to file the application?

examples.jp: 彼はわざわざ私の家に謝りに来た。
examples.en: He came all the way to my place to apologize.

examples.jp: さっきまで、隣の部署から確認しに来ていました。
examples.en: Until a moment ago, someone from the neighboring department had been coming to check.

examples.jp: 買い物に来る予定はありません。
examples.en: I have no plans to come here to shop.

examples.jp: 今日はもう、質問しに来ないでください。
examples.en: Please don’t come to ask questions anymore today.

examples.jp: 先生、今、教室に様子を見に来ていただけますか。
examples.en: Professor, could you please come to the classroom now to check on things?

examples.jp: 友人は新しいカフェに写真を撮りに来なかった。
examples.en: My friend didn’t come to the new café to take photos.

examples.jp: みなさん、この後、体育館に運動しに来てくださいね。
examples.en: Everyone, please come to the gym after this to exercise.

examples.jp: 彼女は何度も同じ質問をしに来る。
examples.en: She keeps coming to ask the same question.

examples.jp: 明日、部屋に荷物を取りにきます。
examples.en: I’ll come to the room tomorrow to pick up the luggage.

examples.jp: さあ、今日はここに遊びに来たんだよね？
examples.en: So, you came here to hang out today, right?

negativeExamples.en: I’ll come to the office tomorrow.

negativeExamples.jp: 公園へ走りに行きます。
negativeExamples.en: I’m going to the park to run.

negativeExamples.jp: ここに来ないでください。

negativeExamples.en: Are you coming to the meeting?

negativeExamples.jp: 荷物を取りに行ってきます。
negativeExamples.en: I’m going to go pick up the luggage and come back.

negativeExamples.jp: パンを買って来ますね。
negativeExamples.en: I’ll go buy some bread and come back.

negativeExamples.jp: 勉強のために来ました。
誰がここに来るのか知っています。
negativeExamples.en: I know who will come here.

negativeExamples.jp: 彼は朝からずっとここに来ています。
negativeExamples.en: He has been here since morning.

negativeExamples.jp: その人は来月日本に来る予定です。
negativeExamples.en: That person plans to come to Japan next month.
